line_1: But sedentary weavers of long tales,
line_2: Give me the fidgets and my patience fails.

line_1: Who, might calm reason credit idle tales,
line_2: By rancour forg'd where prejudice prevails,

line_1: But wayward laugh, or vie in wanton Tales:
line_2: Your Presence gives clear Skies, and pleasing Gales.

line_1: How charm'd I've listen'd to his melting tales;
line_2: Witness ye rural walks and verdant vales,

line_1: Who seeks to purchase Fame by childish Tales.
line_2: Whilst of his Aim the lazy Trifler fails,

line_1: When cleanly servants, if we trust old tales,
line_2: Besides their wages had good fairy vails,

line_1: To fright his sisters with his tales,
line_2: Who travers'd seas, and hills and vales,

line_1: The circling sea-nymphs told alternate tales
And neighb'ring hills resound the moving tales.
line_2: The plaintive sounds shall die along the vales,

line_1: But now, farewell all legendary tales,
From Dryden's Fables down to D—y's Tales.
line_2: All Books he reads, and all he reads assails,

line_1: Heir to his Plays, his Fables and his Tales,
line_2: Con— is the Poetick Prince of Wales;
